botanical_details.genus: Lilium are bulbous perennials with erect stems bearing whorled or spirally arranged leaves and terminal racemes or umbels of bowl-shaped, trumpet-shaped, funnel-shaped or turks cap shaped flowers, often fragrant, and white, yellow, orange or red

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in well-drained soil enriched with leaf mould or well-rotted organic matter in full sun with the base of the plant in shade. In containers or under glass grow in loam-based potting compost (JI No.2) with added grit and leaf mould in full light with shade from hot sun
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by seed as soon as ripe in containers in a cold frame. Bulb propagation: detach bulblets from parent bulb as plants become dormant and pot on; remove bulbils from leaf axils before plants die down and pot on; propagate with scales from healthy bulbs
how_to_grow.pruning: Cut down flower stems when flowering is completed
how_to_grow.pests: lily beetle can be a problem. May also be affected by slugs, thrips, leatherjackets, wireworms and aphids. Small mammals such as rabbits and voles may damage plants
how_to_grow.diseases: Various fungi can affect lilies both above and below ground: grey moulds is sometimes a problem and a virus can affect lilies although some cultivars are virus-tolerant and grow well
